awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Predictive Micro Mobility Management in mmWave Cellular Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to its huge capacity benefits, mmWave communication has been envisioned as a promising high-capacity low-latency solution for 5G systems and beyond, for both indoor (static) and outdoor (mobile) applications. Lagging behind this vision, however, existing research on mmWave communication is mainly focused on static users, while the case of mobile users that move in small scale at pedestrian speed, a.k.a. micro mobility - a typical scenario envisioned for outdoor mmWave applications, has been largely ignored. The challenge of micro mobility stems from the fact that mmWave communication heavily relies on line of sight (LOS) communications, which could be frequently blocked by obstacles during the course of user movement, leading to loss of the received signal and causing link outage. The resulting intermittent connection significantly undermines the performance of higher layers. This project will address the fundamental challenge of micro mobility in outdoor mmWave networks by systematically exploring a suite of prediction-based, cross-layer, seamless, and efficient micro mobility management solutions for realistic multi-obstacle mobile mmWave environments. The research outcome will contribute to the successful development of the nation?s next-generation high-speed cellular communication infrastructure, and hence will create a stronger driving force and carrier for the nation?s economy. This project will also carry out a comprehensive education plan to broaden its impact, with a special emphasis on underrepresented and minority groups.

In contrast to the conventional proactive and reactive mobility management methods, the novelty of this project lies in the development of a new class of predictive link/network-layer designs that enables reaction to an outage before it happens, overcoming the low-efficiency and long-delay weaknesses of existing methods. In particular, an outage prediction mechanism will be proposed to accurately predict when the mmWave LOS will be blocked and how long the blockage will last in realistic multi-obstacle outdoor environment. Taking advantage of the predicted blockage information, the project will propose a multi-scale just-in-time (JIT) predictive outage handling framework. For outage of short durations, cross-layer predictive link/network-layer designs will be proposed to hide outages from upper layers. For outages of long durations, a JIT optimal-stopping sequential handover mechanism will be developed to maximize the handover efficiency and quality of service (QoS) while accounting for the handover overhead and deadline. A mmWave test-bed will also be developed at Auburn University to evaluate all proposed solutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Due to its huge capacity advantages, mmWave communication has been envisioned as a promising high-capacity low-latency solution for 5G systems and beyond. However, a fundamental problem of mmWave communication is its susceptibility to line-of-sight (LOS) blockage, which happens frequently during a mmWave communication, especially for mobile users. When the LOS is blocked by an obstacle, the mmWave signal cannot penetrate through or circumvent around the obstacle, leading to a significant drop of the received signal strength or even link outage. The resulting intermittent connection significantly undermines the performance of higher layers. This project aims to address the above fundamental problem by developing a suite of prediction-based cross-layer resource management methods that exploit users mobility pattern in both the spatial and temporal domains.

The main intellectual merit outcomes of this project include:

1. A fast and high-resolution Non-LOS (NLOS) beam switching mechanism has been developed to allow a commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) mmWave device to promptly identify and turn to the strongest NLOS path in the environment to sustain its communication whenever its original LOS is blocked. A novel method has been developed to support high-resolution mmWave multi-path channel resolving based on coarse-grained wide-beam phased array antennas. A novel real-time beam-switching algorithm is also proposed to allow a COTS device to estimate the location and reflection coefficient of the dominant reflectors in the environment, so that the device will know where to steer its beam when its LOS is blocked.

2. A novel spatial and temporal context-based handover mechanism has been developed to minimize the number of unnecessary handovers for mobile users in ultra-dense mmWave cellular networks. Without assuming prior knowledge of user's mobility and obstacle layout in the environment, the proposed handover mechanism exploits the empirical distribution of user's post-handover trajectory and LOS blockage, learned online through a multi-armed bandit (MAB) framework. As a result, a mobile user is able to decide the optimal base station (BS) it should handover to so that the new user-BS connection after the handover can last as long as possible.

3. A novel bandwidth-efficient MIMO-precoding method has been proposed for ultra-dense cell-free mmWave networks to suppress interference between users without incurring high overhead for communicating the instantaneous channel state information (CSI) between the user and the BS. This is achieved by a novel model-based CSI compression mechanism, which exploits the physical structure of the mmWave Rician fading channels so as to decompose a channel matrix into a LOS and a NLOS components, and then efficiently compresses them using a model-based method and a singular-value-decomposition (SVD)-based method, respectively.

4. A novel (k, α)-coverage problem has been defined and studied in the context of mmWave networks, which aims to deploy the minimum number of reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) in a given area so that any point in the area can be covered by at least k RISs (so there are at least k NLOS paths for each point) and the angular separation between any two adjacent NLOS paths is at least α degrees (the bigger the α, the stronger the capability of circumventing obstacles by these NLOS paths). This optimization problem has been investigated under deterministic RIS deployment and random RIS deployment conditions, respectively. The problem is shown to be NP-complete, and strong feasible solutions and their performance bounds are developed under each RIS deployment condition.

The broader impact outcomes of this project include:

1. This project has significantly advanced the state of the art in the area of mobility management in mmWave networks. Frequent outage caused by user's mobility is a bottleneck to the performance of mmWave networks. This project has provided the much needed solution to this fundamental issue. The research outcomes significantly increase the performance of higher-layer protocols and applications for mmWave networks, hence benefiting the users of the technology. Meanwhile, the proposed research features a predictive link/network layer design, an area that has been under-explored in existing networking research. This project has created new knowledge in this area.

2. The research outcomes have been disseminated to the networking community via publications, talks, and posters. Some of the research results have been integrated into the course materials taught by the PI at the undergraduate and graduate levels. This project has also been introduced to many high-school students at E-days of the Auburn University. This helps to foster the high-school students' interests in taking science and technology as their future career.

3. This project has supported two REU students and several Ph.D. students, including three female Ph.D. students. Three of them have graduated with their Ph.D. degrees. Through this project, they have received rigid training in networking, signal processing, machine learning, and optimization. In addition, they have also acquired hands-on experience in the simulation and testbed development. The above training and hands-on experience will lay a solid foundation for their future career development.
